metadata.description: The attacker uses social engineering to convince the agent to open a malicious email attachment. The email contains a malicious Word document.

context: The email attachment was a malicious Word Document

metadata.description: The agent executes the malicious attachment, triggered by the attacker. The malicious Word document contains the encoded .VBS script.

context: The malicious VB Script will use macros to search for instances of Microsoft Word running on the system

metadata.description: This involves the use of Visual Basic scripts to execute commands on the system, which is what the malicious VB Script is doing.

context: The victim system will then reach out to http://95.215.47.105 to retrieve additional malware called AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs

metadata.description: This technique involves transferring tools or files from an external system into the victim environment. The victim system retrieves the additional malware from http

context: Adds file to WindowsUpdate folder: vbs

metadata.description: This technique involves transferring tools or files to the victim system. The malware adds the VBS file to the `WindowsUpdate` folder.

context: Adds persistence mechanism to the CURRENT_USER registry hive in the CurrentVersion\Run and CurrentVersion\RunOnce keys to autostart AdobeUpdateManagementTool.

metadata.description: This technique involves adding registry keys to automatically execute programs upon user logon. The malware adds entries to the `CurrentVersion\Run` and `CurrentVersion\RunOnce` keys.

context: A scheduled task is created named SysChecks which calls the vbs

metadata.description: This technique involves using scheduled tasks for persistence. The malware creates a scheduled task named `SysChecks` to execute the VBS script.

context: A service is created named 'ADOBEUPDTOOL' which calls the AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs

metadata.description: This technique involves creating or modifying Windows services for persistence or to execute malicious code.
metadata.note: A service named 'ADOBEUPDTOOL' is created to call the `AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs`.

metadata.note: The malware attempts to download a file (possibly a document) from an external server.

context: This malware was capable of stealing significant system and network information

metadata.description: Adversaries may attempt to get detailed information about the system they are targeting.
metadata.note: The malware is capable of stealing significant system information.

context: It was also used to download several other reconnaissance tools to map out the network.

metadata.description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment.
metadata.note: The malware downloads several reconnaissance tools such as Nmap, FreeRDP, NCat, NPing, and others.

context: could execute powershell scripts on command

metadata.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.
metadata.note: The malware can execute PowerShell scripts on command.

context: Beaconing messages are sent out to 179.43.133.34 via standard HTTP GET requests every 5 minutes

metadata.description: Adversaries may use web protocols like HTTP to communicate with their command and control (C2) servers.
metadata.note: Beaconing messages are sent out via standard HTTP GET requests, indicating the use of HTTP for communication.

context: The content of the GET request is encoded with Base64 and secondarily encrypted with RC4

metadata.description: Adversaries may use various methods to obfuscate data to evade detection.
metadata.note: The content of the GET request is Base64 encoded and encrypted with RC4, indicating an attempt to obfuscate the traffic.

context: This malware executes a new iteration of svchost.exe and injects its malicious code into this running process

metadata.description: Adversaries may inject code into the address space of another process to evade detection and achieve persistence.
metadata.note: The malware injects its code into a running `svchost.exe` process to hide its presence.

context: It then drops a pseudo-randomly named configuration file into the %ProgramData%\Mozilla folder. This file's name is base64 encoded and based on the infected system's MAC code, so identifying it by name will be challenging.

metadata.description: Adversaries may use masquerading to disguise their files or processes as something legitimate to avoid detection.
metadata.note: The malware drops a configuration file with a pseudo-random name and a `.bin` extension, making it harder to identify or distinguish from legitimate files. The name is based on the MAC address and is base64 encoded to further obfuscate its purpose.

context: It then searches Kaspersky antivirus processes and terminates them if running on the victim system.

metadata.description: Adversaries may disable or interfere with security tools to prevent them from detecting or responding to the attack.
metadata.note: Specifically, terminating antivirus processes falls under this technique as it directly impacts the functionality of security tools on the system.

context: It then searches Kaspersky antivirus processes and terminates them if running on the victim system.

metadata.description: The malware searches Kaspersky antivirus processes and terminates them if running on the victim system.

context: it registers itself as a service with the following details: Service name: RpcSsSys (this name is random, may vary on different system)

metadata.description: Adversaries may create or modify Windows services to ensure their malware runs automatically when the system starts or when a service is started.
metadata.note: The text describes registering the malware as a Windows service with a specific service name, path, and display name, which aligns with creating or modifying a system service for persistence.

context: steal local passwords

metadata.description: Adversaries may dump credentials to obtain user passwords or hashes.
metadata.note: The malware's ability to steal local passwords indicates it may use credential dumping techniques.

context: install completely different remote desktop programs, such as VNC or AMMYY

metadata.description: Adversaries may use remote access tools to control systems and maintain persistence.
metadata.note: The installation of remote desktop programs (such as VNC or AMMYY) is a classic example of using remote access tools for control and persistence.

context: It communicates via an encrypted tunnel on port 443

metadata.description: Adversaries use application layer protocols for command and control (C2) communications.
metadata.note: The malware communicates via an encrypted tunnel over port 443 and sends data via HTTP POST messages.

context: The file is OLE compound file format that contains an embedded .VBE (encoded VBS) script

metadata.description: This technique involves the use of scripting languages such as VBS (Visual Basic Script) to execute malicious actions. The .VBE (encoded VBS) script is a form of scripting used to perform various actions.
metadata.note: The embedded .VBE script in the OLE compound file performs actions such as stealing system information and screenshots, and downloading additional malware.

context: stealing system information

context: When the malicious document file is opened, the embedded VBScript (VBE) file is dropped in the Windows %temp% folder.

metadata.description: This technique involves configuring the system to execute the malicious payload during system boot or user logon. Although not directly related to dropping the VBScript, the placement in %temp% could be part of a persistence mechanism.

context: The dropped VBE file is a loader script that drops, installs and executes

metadata.description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment.

context: a second layer VBScript payload in the victim's system.

metadata.description: This technique involves the use of scripting languages such as VBS (Visual Basic Script) to execute malicious actions.

context: It creates a folder named "WindowsUpdate_" in the Window's %temp% directory, If the folder already exists, it will create the folder in the parent directory where the script resides.

metadata.description: This technique involves disguising files or processes to make them appear legitimate. The creation of the "WindowsUpdate_" folder and the naming conventions used may be attempts to blend in with legitimate system operations.
metadata.note: The folder named "WindowsUpdate_" is an example of masquerading, as it attempts to appear as a legitimate Windows folder.

context: A registry key is created that points to the Loader's directory sh.RegWriTe"HKEY_CURRENT_USER\System\CurrentControlSet\Control

metadata.description: This technique involves creating or modifying registry entries to ensure that the malware executes automatically upon system boot or user logon.
metadata.note: y creating a registry key that points to the directory containing the loader, the malware can ensure that its components are executed automatically when the system starts or when a user logs in.

context: The second VBScript payload is embedded in the loader script as a Base64 string

metadata.description: This technique involves encoding or obfuscating files or information to hide their true purpose. The use of Base64 encoding is a form of obfuscation that helps to evade detection by making the payload less recognizable.
metadata.note: The second VBScript payload is encoded in Base64 to obscure its content within the loader script.

context: The loader script decodes the base64 string

metadata.description: This technique involves decoding or deobfuscating information to make it usable. The loader script decodes the Base64 string to retrieve the VBScript payload.
metadata.note: The decoding process is a key step in making the malicious VBScript operational.

context: This is then saved to a file named "AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs" into the "\WindowsUpdate_" folder

metadata.description: This technique involves transferring tools or files into a compromised system. The VBScript file is saved and created in the target system's directory.
metadata.note: The decoded VBScript is saved to a file in the \WindowsUpdate_ folder, transferring the malicious payload onto the system.

context: A persistence registry key is also created by the loader script: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run

metadata.description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key. These mechanisms ensure that the program runs each time the user logs in or the system starts.
metadata.note: The loader script creates a registry key under `HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run` to ensure that the script runs at startup, providing persistence on the infected system.

context: The loader script adds a scheduled task with a task named "SysChecks". The purpose of this scheduled task is to run the payload script (AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs) in every 5 minutes

metadata.description: Adversaries may abuse task scheduling functionality to facilitate initial or recurring execution of malicious code. This can be used to execute code at a specific time or on a recurring schedule.
metadata.note: The loader script creates a scheduled task named "SysChecks" to run the payload script (AdobeUpdateManagementTool.vbs) every 5 minutes. This ensures that the malicious script executes periodically, maintaining the persistence of the malware.

context: A SWF icon file is also dropped in the folder in order to disguise the dropped file as a Shockwave Flash file

metadata.description: Adversaries may change the file extension of a file to match a different file type. They can use this tactic to disguise files as benign or known types, making them less likely to be detected or scrutinized by security tools or users.
metadata.note: The malware drops a SWF (Shockwave Flash) icon file to disguise the dropped file as a Shockwave Flash file. This masquerading helps evade detection by making the malicious file appear as a legitimate and familiar file type.

context: A shortcut file is also added in the Windows startup folder as "AdobeUpdateManagementTool.lnk"

metadata.description: Adversaries may create or modify shortcut files (.lnk) that are automatically started at boot or logon to execute malware or other malicious code. This technique involves placing shortcuts in specific locations, such as the startup folder, to achieve persistence.
metadata.note: The malware adds a shortcut file named "AdobeUpdateManagementTool.lnk" in the Windows startup folder. This ensures that the malware runs every time the system starts, providing a persistent foothold on the infected system.

context: script uses obfuscation, a combination of base64 and integer-ed characters (chr) to hide malicious code

metadata.description: The use of base64 encoding and integer-ed characters (chr) to obfuscate the script. This more accurately reflects the described obfuscation of the VBScript payload.

context: it registers itself as a service with the following details: Service name: RpcSsSys (this name is random, may vary on different systems)

metadata.description: The malware creates a new Windows service to ensure its persistence. It sets up the service with a path that disguises its true nature, often using a name that mimics legitimate services.

context: The malware checks for the "isDebugged" flag in the PEB (Process Environment Block). It also checks for significant delay of code execution by utilizing the GetTickCount() function.

metadata.description: The malware checks the \"isDebugged\" flag in the PEB (Process Environment Block) and also checks for significant delay of code execution by utilizing the GetTickCount() function to detect if the process is being debugged

context: Strings are heavily obfuscated to avoid static string analysis

metadata.description: Strings are obfuscated to avoid static string analysis

context: The malware enables the Remote Desktop by starting the Termservice service

metadata.description: This technique involves using remote services such as Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) or other remote access tools. Enabling and configuring Remote Desktop is a direct use of this technique to maintain access to the system.

context: It also sets the service to auto-mode so that the service will start on Windows startup.

metadata.description: Modifying the Termservice service to start automatically on Windows startup is a form of persistence where the malware ensures that it will be able to reconnect to the system after a reboot.

context: The malware utilizes the open source project called Mimikatz and reused codes from this project to steal clear text local passwords from Lsass memory dump.

metadata.description: This technique involves extracting credentials from operating system memory, files, or other sources. Mimikatz is a well-known tool for credential dumping, and its use to extract passwords from LSASS memory falls directly under this technique.

context: $"  ammyy.pl- this enables the malware to run AMMYY remote desktop control software %"  vnc.pl- this enables the malware to run a remote desktop VNC application

metadata.description: This technique involves the use of Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) for remote access to systems. While the text specifically mentions Ammyy and VNC, RDP is a common protocol for similar purposes.
